overview_of_class:
Over the last fifty years, billions of dollars have been given to developing countries, yet critics argue that international aid is ineffectual and, worse yet, harmful to recipients. In this course, we will examine the politics surrounding the delivery of international aid, debating questions such as who gets to decides the aid agenda, which countries should receive what aid and, once delivered, how impact changes political dynamics in recipient communities. The substantive content of this course will expose students to current trends and debates in the world of international aid, highlighting how politics pervades even the most ?technical' of aid interventions.

The course blends traditional seminar-style discussions with the Harvard Business School case method. This teaching method asks students to collectively make a decision in a real-world case involving international aid. The case method highlights to students the complexities (including the many ethical dimensions) of aid work, encouraging students to develop their ability to articulate clear, persuasive arguments and engage in complex negotiations with their classmates in the process.

overview_of_class: It isn't easy being a superpower. For the past 50 years, U.S. policymakers have struggled to define America's role in an ever more complex world where threats multiply and challenges morph and endure. The period beginning with the Vietnam War traces an arc that reaches from Soviet nuclear arsenals to Islamic suicide bombers, from a fear of falling dominoes in Southeast Asia to hopes for a wave of democracy in the Middle East. This course uses an engaging set of examples and materials to chart one of the most intriguing stretches of international engagement in U.S. History. We will work collaboratively to understand why decisions were made, how policies were implemented and sold, and what it all may mean in the end. Assessing sources from presidential speeches and critics' rejoinders to film documentaries and media accounts, we will study goals and motivations, ends and means in an array of case studies. With the significant added bonus of considering foreign policy as an issue in the 2016 presidential campaign. We will pay particular attention to current events in the Middle East and its surroundings, including Syria, Iran, Israel and Iraq.

overview_of_class: The number of refugees, asylum-seekers and internally displaced people worldwide has, for the first time in the post-World War II era, exceeded 50 million people. 16 million of the displaced are refugees. In this course we examine the international and state response to refugee crisis. In order to understand the responsibilities and challenges of responding to refugee crises today, we will look back historically at the creation of the 1951 Refugee Convention regime. We will learn about how the regime was created in response to the plight of refugees in WWII, the failure to take into account the crises of partition in South Asia and the Middle East leading those states to opt out of the Refugee Convention regime and the implications of this history for today's crises. We will consider the challenges of international and regional cooperation. Drawing on case studies we will critically examine different international responses, the constraints of international and regional cooperation in managing a crisis, the politics of camp and urban refugees, why crises become protracted, populations are rendered stateless and the role of human rights in responding to their predicament. Finally, we consider how the new (or not new) ways in which refugee flight takes place (smuggling, migrants at sea, privatization) is a response to the conditions of displacement in camps and urban areas and increasing state securitization.

overview_of_class:
For much of the world's population, land sustains livelihoods, shapes identities, and provides a source of
investment and security. Yet the centrality of land in everyday life also means that it can become a
source of contentious politics and violence. This class explores how struggles over access and rights to
land shape different forms of conflict and violence: between squatters and state officials, different
ethnic groups, or armed groups and the state.

The course explores questions of land and conflict in several parts. We begin by examining the question
of land meanings: what does land, property, and territory mean to different groups of people? How
does this help us understand why people organize or fight around issues of land? Second, the course
takes an historical and comparative view of the rules and institutions that shape people's rights and
access to land. The third part of the class explores theories that link land to conflict and violence. We
then apply these theories to explore a set of case studies of land-related conflict: from the recent armed
uprising in Oregon to civil war in Colombia. The last part of the class moves toward policy
considerations. How, for example, can a focus on land rights improve post-conflict resolution?
The course is interdisciplinary in its approach, drawing heavily on political science and political
geography. It should appeal to students interested in peace and conflict issues, environmental politics,
international development, and human rights.

overview_of_class:
Global Democracy and World Disorder: Challenges in Africa and Beyond

This course will explore the evolution from the "democratic euphoria" of the early 1990s, to the sober analyses of democratization later in that same decade, to the current theoretical and empirical challenges. The experiences of specific countries in a few world regions will be examined closely.

After the Cold War, the number of democracies in the world increased significantly. In recent years, however, that number has stagnated and even, by some accounts, declined. The global system today is characterized by growing insecurity and uncertainty. The aim of this course is to achieve a deeper understanding of these dynamics and their implications.

The expansion of liberal democracies and liberalized economies was adversely affected by the 9/11 Al Qaeda attack on the World Trade Center and the prolonged wars that followed in Iraq, Afghanistan, and Syria. The relentless upsurge in jihadist insurgencies has steadily shifted global priorities to the strengthening of security and political order.

The rise of China and the resurgence of authoritarianism in Russia have contributed to the complexities and uncertainties. So also have the erosion of state systems, forced migrations,and the upsurge in ethnic nationalism and religious sectarianism. The failures of the Arab Spring, and the fracturing of Iraq, Syria, and Libya have had wide ramifications.

Is liberal democracy being eclipsed by new forms of authoritarianism, or is it proving resilient and adaptive? Where are these trends and others evident? Writing in the Journal of Democracy about the "renewed struggle between democracy and authoritarianism worldwide", Christopher Walker recently wrote: [Authoritarian] regimes show solidarity and coordination with one another, at least when it comes to contesting and containing democracy and the ideas central to it. Through this more internationalist approach and authoritarian learning, China, Russia, Iran, and other illiberal regimes have developed instruments to counter the democratic West's soft power." For these developments in Africa, see an essay by this course instructor: http://www.brookings.edu/research/opinions/2016/01/07-democracy-state-power-africa-joseph.

overview_of_class: The seminar is designed for students intending to engage in community-based research with international NGO partners. These research projects should be substantive community development investigations that students undertake in collaboration with international NGOs or government agencies, or other community-based organizations or groups. The projects should be designed to respond effectively to community development information needs of the NGO partners, to build new knowledge and skills for students, and ultimately to contribute to improved life for residents served by these NGOs. The seminar will introduce students to rationales, approaches, methods and controversies related to partnership-based, community research and to their community-based research partners. It will introduce students to principles and effective practice in effective collaboration with Community research partners and data sources. It will enable students to prepare for, plan, and launch their projects in collaboration with these partners. While open to all students, the seminar should be taken by all students intending to undertake research over the summer as Buffet Center research fellows.

overview_of_class: This course explores historical formation of cities and citizenry in the Middle East since the 19th century. It studies urban development, economy, social classes and politics in Egypt and Turkey with a focus on two world-historical cities, Cairo and Istanbul. Drawing mostly on readings in history, anthropology and sociology, it examines how urban space in Egypt and Turkey was reconfigured through histories of colonialism, nationalism, developmentalism and globalization with a particular attention to the following topics: urban immigration, informality, gendered places, consumption, urban regeneration, local politics and branding the city. Throughout the course, these topics are studied in relation to two main questions: How do spatial changes engender new social practices and redefine cultural difference and vice versa?; How do power struggles at the intersection of local and global interests shape urban change? The course is designed for history, sociology, anthropology, political science and urban studies majors.
